Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Consequences of adaptive behavioral plasticity for selection on an acoustic signal
Award.AbstractNarration:
A central problem in evolutionary biology is understanding how flexibility (termed plasticity) in the expression of traits functions when populations are under selection: does flexibility facilitate or hamper evolution? Flexibility could facilitate evolution by creating new traits on which selection could act; alternatively, flexibility could hamper evolution by protecting genes for detrimental traits from being selected. Flexibility in mating behavior can be especially important because it could allow the maintenance of small or isolated populations, where available mates of preferred types are few, or play a role in the divergence of populations, ultimately leading to divergence of one species into two or more. This project addresses this fundamental question by examining how flexibility in mate preference could affect the evolution of courtship. During this project, a graduate student and an undergraduate participant will gain comprehensive research experience in behavioral ecology and bioacoustics. In addition, the researchers will engage in science education and outreach activities aimed at elementary school children, adults in non-science careers, and members of underrepresented groups in science via hands-on science activities, public appearances, and writing for non-technical audiences.

This project examines how the experience of male song quality during development affects female mating behavior in the Pacific field cricket. Male crickets produce song that females use to identify and localize appropriate mates. Within Hawaii, the crickets experience a novel selection pressure against singing preferred songs: an acoustically orienting parasitoid fly that preferentially infests males with the same song characteristics preferred by female crickets. Recently, a mutation arose that makes male crickets obligately silent ('flatwing'). Female crickets strongly prefer singing males, and also have directional preferences about temporal properties of the song. Plasticity in expression of these preferences could facilitate maintenance of this population when available males of preferred phenotypes are few, but this plasticity could have consequences for the strength of selection on sexual signals. Indeed, both males and females reared in silence, mimicking an all-mutant environment, become more phonotactic, suggesting that mating behavior is plastic and selection on signals in nature may be relaxed. In this study, the researchers will rear crickets in acoustic environments that vary by the value of a preferred trait and use phonotaxis trials (females) and song recordings (males) to determine: 1) whether signal production is plastic; 2) whether expression of female mating preferences is plastic; 3) whether population differences in the extent of this plasticity support the hypothesis that plasticity in mating behavior is an adaptive response following the introduction of flatwing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Male crickets typically sing to attract mates, and females typically have strong preferences for particular song qualities. On several islands of Hawaii, some male crickets lack the ability to sing as a result of a sex-linked mutation. As a result, there are few males singing in the environment. Our goal in this project was to determine how the dynamics of this system might affect the evolution of the song itself, by examining how female experience of song shapes their mate choice. Are female preferences for song dependent on the song quality they experience growing up?

            We tested a hypothesis called the “mate assurance in a variable environment hypothesis,” which posits that females should adjust their preferences to be choosier when preferred mates are widely available, and less choosy when preferred mates are absent. This would protect females from mating with low quality males when preferred males are common and from being too picky to mate at all when preferred males are absent. We expected variation between islands in the environmental factors that select for this tendency to have different preferences in different environments.

            Our data generally supported the hypothesis that females adjust their preferences based on their experience, but only when they live in an environment that is variable with respect to the availability of preferred mates. Females from Oahu, where the conditions are most variable with regard to the availability of preferred males, had the most variable preferences of all the populations. Oahu females were somewhat more likely to be attracted to songs with higher proportions of long chirp (a feature that females care about) if they had grown up in the presence of attractive songs. Females from the other two populations, where the availability of high-quality mates is not variable, did not have plastic preferences for song quality.

            With this Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant, the graduate student was able to substantially expand the scope of her dissertation work, including completing additional field work in the Hawaiian archipelago, the only place in the world she could study these populations of crickets losing their ability to sing. She and the PI also provided training to an undergraduate researcher, who gained experience and mentorship science research.

            The results of this work are to be published in an academic paper, which is currently in preparation for submission to a leading journal in our field. Our findings were also presented widely to academic audiences in the United States (including U. of Minnesota, U of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, U. of Nebraska) by the co-PI and PI, as well as communicated to diverse members of the public through several public lectures delivered by the PI. The co-PI also presented the results to an academic audience in Perth, Western Australia.

During the period of the grant, the co-PI’s efforts to broaden the impact of her work included hands-on science outreach activities on the topics of animal communication and the evolution of behavior. She worked in collaboration with the Animal Behavior Society Outreach Fair to reach more than 400 people, mainly children and their families, in Boulder, CO and Princeton, NJ. In collaboration with the University of Western Australia’s School of Indigenous Studies, the co-PI conducted 5 different lessons with groups of about 30 indigenous students, grades 8 through 10, from throughout Western Australia. The primary goals of these outreach activities were 1) to broaden representation of underrepresented groups, including indigenous people, in science research by demystifying the process and stoking interest in biological topics and 2) to increase public engagement with, and understanding of, evolution.
